description: From Middle French nocturnal, from Latin nocturnus (“nocturnal, nightly”), from Latin nox (“night”), from Proto-Indo-European *nókʷts (“night”). Cognates include Ancient Greek νύξ (núx), Sanskrit नक्ति (nákti), Old English niht (English night) and Proto-Slavic *noťь.

adjectives.description: nocturnal (comparative more nocturnal, superlative most nocturnal)

entries.meaning: (of a person, creature, group, or species) Primarily active during the night.
(of an occurrence) Taking place at night, nightly.
A person or creature that is active at night.
(historical) A device for telling the time at night, rather like a sundial but read according to the stars.
